Triple Your HarmonyOS App Development Speed with Claude Code + Documentation-Driven Programming + BDD Business-Driven Testing

Sep 26, 2025
Vibe Sparking

This methodology specifically addresses three major pain points: ‚ÄúAI can write code but doesn‚Äôt understand HarmonyOS,‚Äù ‚ÄúArkTS keeps throwing errors,‚Äù and ‚Äúregression testing can‚Äôt keep up.‚Äù The core principle: Drive Claude Code with documentation, and secure quality through BDD automation.

Introduction: Don‚Äôt Chat Randomly with AI ‚Äì Write Good Documentation First

Section titled ‚ÄúIntroduction: Don‚Äôt Chat Randomly with AI ‚Äì Write Good Documentation First‚Äù

Many developers immediately tell AI: ‚ÄúHelp me build a HarmonyOS app for Bluetooth scanning, connecting, and time synchronization.‚Äù The result? Claude Code produces seemingly sophisticated code that turns completely red upon compilation. Are you familiar with ArkTS? Do you understand the ArkUI lifecycle? How do you handle regression testing? All uncertain.

HarmonyOS officially provides ArkTS coding standards, ArkUI declarative development paradigms, and performance practices ‚Äì these are standard components that Claude Code ‚Äúcrashes repeatedly if not learned properly.‚Äù ArkTS is HarmonyOS‚Äôs primary language, sharing roots with TypeScript but having its own semantics and ecosystem. Writing with old JavaScript habits makes it easy to fall into traps. The good news is: Claude Code already supports ‚Äúreading repositories, editing files, writing and running tests, executing terminal commands.‚Äù As long as you provide the right context, it can consistently produce engineered results.

I. Documentation-Driven Programming: Make Claude Code Follow Your Lead

Section titled ‚ÄúI. Documentation-Driven Programming: Make Claude Code Follow Your Lead‚Äù

Objective: Clearly explain requirements, value, implementation, and acceptance criteria on one page; let Claude Code ‚Äúbuild according to specifications‚Äù within the HarmonyOS context.

1) Write ‚ÄúOne-Page‚Äù Requirements (can be directly placed in repository /docs/feature-xxx.md)

Section titled ‚Äú1) Write ‚ÄúOne-Page‚Äù Requirements (can be directly placed in repository /docs/feature-xxx.md)‚Äù

  • Functionality: Bluetooth device scanning ‚Üí list display ‚Üí connection ‚Üí time synchronization ‚Üí status reading ‚Üí command sending ‚Üí disconnection

  • Business Value: Store associates complete device initialization in 1 minute, reducing manual errors by 80%

  • Platform: HarmonyOS NEXT, ArkTS + ArkUI; DevEco Studio build

  • Interface/Model: Device names start with XX; display battery level after connection; ‚Äúinjection‚Äù command returns success flag

  • Acceptance Criteria (BDD format):

    • Given Application is on the home page
    • When Click ‚ÄúStart Scan‚Äù, see device starting with XX in list and click Connect
    • Then Enter connected page, see device name/battery level; clicking ‚ÄúSync Time,‚Äù ‚ÄúRefresh Status,‚Äù ‚ÄúSend Injection Command‚Äù all return success

Remember to include key ArkTS/ArkUI constraints and best practices in documentation: naming, state management, performance considerations, etc. (from official style guides and state management guidelines). Provide specifications directly to Claude Code ‚Äì it will follow these rules during generation.

2) Initial System Prompt for Claude Code (place in .claude/primer.md)

Section titled ‚Äú2) Initial System Prompt for Claude Code (place in .claude/primer.md)‚Äù
  • Project framework (ArkUI page structure, directory conventions)
  • ArkTS code style requirements (variable/component naming, null checks, error handling)
  • Component inventory & event flow (Button ‚Üí scanning ‚Üí list ‚Üí connection)
  • Test-first approach: Generate BDD scenarios and ArkTS test stubs first, then supplement business code
  • Failure retry: compilation error ‚Üí read error ‚Üí modify minimal set only

Officials and community both emphasize standards-driven coding, which significantly reduces rework and performance issues. Claude Code itself also recommends customizing context and environment (e.g., ignoring irrelevant files, providing dedicated README/CONTRIBUTING), which can significantly improve hit rates.

3) Place ‚ÄúProcess Description + Acceptance Steps‚Äù in README

Section titled ‚Äú3) Place ‚ÄúProcess Description + Acceptance Steps‚Äù in README‚Äù

The image below shows our manual acceptance steps for this feature, used for manual verification and providing context for Claude Code:

This text will be absorbed by Claude Code as ‚Äúexecutable documentation‚Äù: it can write UI flows first, then supplement logic and tests (Claude officially claims to ‚Äúwrite and run tests, edit files, commit code‚Äù).

II. BDD Business-Driven Testing: Transform ‚ÄúDocumentation‚Äù into ‚ÄúExecutable Specifications‚Äù

Section titled ‚ÄúII. BDD Business-Driven Testing: Transform ‚ÄúDocumentation‚Äù into ‚ÄúExecutable Specifications‚Äù‚Äù

In one sentence: Write requirements as Gherkin scenarios, run tests on DevEco/arkXtest framework, test red ‚Üí AI fix ‚Üí test green again.

1) Describe Business with Gherkin

Section titled ‚Äú1) Describe Business with Gherkin‚Äù

The advantage of Gherkin/BDD is transforming ‚Äúbusiness language‚Äù directly into executable specifications, continuously validating whether system behavior matches documentation.

2) ArkTS Testing Implementation Selection

Section titled ‚Äú2) ArkTS Testing Implementation Selection‚Äù
  • DevEco/arkXtest System: Provides unified framework for unit testing + UI testing + performance testing; UI test scripts execute on top of unit tests, meeting end-to-end validation needs.
  • IDE Support: DevEco Studio integrates testing framework and code test entry points, facilitating execution on real devices/simulators.

Some documentation also mentions HarmonyOS/ArkTS testing capability upgrades in the NEXT version, supporting more modern syntax and parameterization techniques, which can be adopted in your engineering templates as needed (based on official and authoritative sources).

3) Example: UI Scenario Test Framework (extracted from actual project structure)

Section titled ‚Äú3) Example: UI Scenario Test Framework (extracted from actual project structure)‚Äù

This test does three things:

  1. If not scanned, try clicking ‚ÄúStart Scan,‚Äù otherwise log and skip
  2. Wait for device discovery
  3. Locate device with specified prefix and click connect, assert entry to connected page

This type of UI test case structure aligns with arkXtest‚Äôs design philosophy: drive UI operations with APIs, consolidate results uniformly in the testing framework.

4) Make ‚ÄúTest Red ‚Üí AI Fix ‚Üí Test Green Again‚Äù a Pipeline

Section titled ‚Äú4) Make ‚ÄúTest Red ‚Üí AI Fix ‚Üí Test Green Again‚Äù a Pipeline‚Äù
  • Claude Code Loop: When failures occur, paste compilation/runtime logs back into conversation for minimal modification fixes (Claude‚Äôs official ‚Äúenvironment tuning + context minimization‚Äù recommendations are crucial here).
  • IDE/CI Integration: One-click execution in DevEco Studio locally; CI integration with real devices/simulators for regression (refer to DevEco test entry points and official testing documentation).
  • Visual Acceptance: Place the manual acceptance step diagrams above in wiki, run Gherkin + UI tests for each version, ensuring ‚Äúdocumentation is truth.‚Äù

III. Implementation Manual: 7-Step Checklist from 0 to 1

Section titled ‚ÄúIII. Implementation Manual: 7-Step Checklist from 0 to 1‚Äù

Step 1 | Project Initialization

  • Create ArkTS project in DevEco Studio; select ArkUI declarative paradigm; confirm target API/device.
  • Recommend pulling ArkTS style guide and performance practices into repository /guides for both human and AI reference.

Step 2 | One-Page Requirements

  • Clearly write functionality, value, interfaces, states, exceptions, acceptance scenarios (Given/When/Then).
  • Place screenshot-style manual acceptance steps in README (the diagram section above).

Step 3 | Claude Code Startup

  • Use .claude/primer.md and /docs as primary context; limit it from reading irrelevant large files.
  • Have it generate test stubs & Gherkin first, then supplement business code and ArkUI pages.

Step 4 | ArkTS/ArkUI Coding

  • Follow naming, componentization, state management constraints; pay attention to performance practices and null/exception handling.

Step 5 | Test Implementation

  • Use arkXtest / DevEco testing for unit tests + UI tests; use Gherkin as top-level use case description (can call UI test APIs in step definitions).

Step 6 | Iterative Fixes

  • Feed failure logs to Claude Code for minimal fixes; loop locally/CI until all green.

Step 7 | Knowledge Base Accumulation

  • Record pitfalls & FAQ in /kb: such as BLE permissions, lifecycle, list performance.
  • Next time, only need to modify ‚Äúone-page‚Äù requirements and a few step descriptions, Claude Code can reuse context to continue generation.

IV. Results: Quality, Speed, and Understanding ‚Äì Triple Success

Section titled ‚ÄúIV. Results: Quality, Speed, and Understanding ‚Äì Triple Success‚Äù
  • Speed: With the ‚Äúdocumentation as code‚Äù approach, Claude Code is more stable on HarmonyOS projects, reducing back-and-forth guessing.
  • Quality: arkXtest + DevEco testing aligns unit tests/UI/performance, automates regression, leaving manual work for exploratory validation only.
  • Understanding: Standards and performance practices written in documentation, humans and AI follow the same rules, new team members can master ArkTS/ArkUI basics in 1 day.

V. Replicable Template (You Can Copy Directly)

Section titled ‚ÄúV. Replicable Template (You Can Copy Directly)‚Äù

Recommended Documentation Directory

Section titled ‚ÄúRecommended Documentation Directory‚Äù

feature-ble-connect.md Fragment

Section titled ‚Äúfeature-ble-connect.md Fragment‚Äù
  • Background/Value
  • Constraints (API/permissions/device prefix)
  • Acceptance Scenarios (5-7 Given/When/Then items)
  • Rollout/rollback strategy

Conclusion: Close the Loop Between ‚ÄúDocumentation‚ÄîTesting‚ÄîCode‚Äù

Section titled ‚ÄúConclusion: Close the Loop Between ‚ÄúDocumentation‚ÄîTesting‚ÄîCode‚Äù‚Äù

When you write documentation that can directly accept, Claude Code has the possibility to write correct ArkTS on the first try; When you get BDD scenarios running, each version can have one-click regression. This is how we consistently achieve ‚Äúfaster speed + more stable quality‚Äù in HarmonyOS projects.

Outperforming the Market for Everyday Investors: The 5:2:1 Allocation Strategy with S&P 500, Nasdaq 100, and VGT

Sep 25, 2025
Vibe Sparking

TL;DR

Section titled ‚ÄúTL;DR‚Äù
  • Allocate your portfolio across three U.S. stock index funds using a 5:2:1 ratio (S&P 500 : Nasdaq 100 : Information Technology Sector).
  • Adhere to a long-term holding strategy with periodic rebalancing, dynamically fine-tuning based on capital size, return objectives, and risk tolerance.

A successful investor owes 85% to correct asset allocation, 10% to the skill of selecting investment targets, and 5% to the grace of God. ‚Äî William F. Sharpe

Long-term investing follows the principle of ‚Äúsimplicity is the ultimate sophistication‚Äù: ordinary investors can achieve substantial asset growth simply by holding one or two U.S. stock index funds over the long run. As a composite index of the 500 largest companies by market capitalization in the U.S. stock market, the S&P 500 covers major industries such as information technology, consumer discretionary, financials, and healthcare, and is widely regarded as a barometer of the overall performance of the U.S. stock market. For instance, the legendary investor Warren Buffett has repeatedly recommended S&P 500 index funds and stipulated in his will that 90% of his personal assets be invested in them, demonstrating his confidence in the index‚Äôs long-term, stable returns.

However, an S&P 500 index fund is not the only option. Depending on their risk appetite, investors can also add a Nasdaq 100 index fund and an information technology sector fund (VGT) to construct a ‚Äútripod‚Äù portfolio of U.S. stock index funds. Below, we introduce these three types of index funds worthy of long-term holding and explain how to allocate them according to a 5:2:1 ratio.

S&P 500 Index Fund: The Cornerstone of the U.S. Stock Market

Section titled ‚ÄúS&P 500 Index Fund: The Cornerstone of the U.S. Stock Market‚Äù

The S&P 500 Index is composed of the 500 largest U.S. public companies by market capitalization, spanning a wide range of sectors from technology and consumer goods to energy and utilities. Due to its diversified components and dispersed weights, the S&P 500 index fund is often considered the primary core asset for investing in the U.S. stock market. Historical data shows that the S&P 500 has a long-term annualized return of around 10%, with relatively moderate volatility, making it suitable for most investors seeking stable growth.

Advantages

Section titled ‚ÄúAdvantages‚Äù
  • Diversification: Covering 500 companies, it does not rely on individual stocks, thus fully diversifying unsystematic risk. The index components account for the vast majority of the U.S. stock market‚Äôs capitalization, effectively allowing one to ‚Äúbuy the U.S. economy in one click.‚Äù
  • Long-term Stable Growth: It has consistently reached new highs through multiple bull and bear cycles, with a high probability of achieving positive returns over long rolling periods.
  • Endorsement by Investment Masters: Many investment gurus advocate for regular investment in S&P 500 index funds; Buffett has long recommended a ‚Äúbuy and hold‚Äù strategy.

It is important to note that S&P 500 index funds are still subject to periodic drawdowns due to economic cycles, but their volatility risk is lower compared to narrower-based indices. For investors with average risk tolerance, an S&P 500 index fund can serve as a single, lifelong holding.

Nasdaq 100 Index Fund: High-Growth Opportunities in Tech Leaders

Section titled ‚ÄúNasdaq 100 Index Fund: High-Growth Opportunities in Tech Leaders‚Äù

The Nasdaq-100 Index consists of the 100 largest non-financial companies listed on the Nasdaq Stock Market and is renowned for its high weighting in technology stocks. The index includes tech giants such as Apple, Microsoft, Alphabet (Google‚Äôs parent company), Amazon, and Nvidia. By providing concentrated exposure to high-growth sectors, the Nasdaq-100 has delivered a significantly higher annualized total return than the S&P 500 over the past few decades.

The characteristics of a Nasdaq 100 index fund can be summarized as follows:

  • Heavy Allocation to Tech Growth: A high proportion of high-growth sectors like information technology results in long-term returns that often outperform the broader market.
  • Higher Volatility: High returns are accompanied by high volatility, with more severe drawdowns during market downturns (e.g., the periods of 2000‚Äì2002 and 2022).
  • Bias Towards Emerging Industries: Components are predominantly from fields like technology, communication services, and consumer discretionary, aligning with future trends but exhibiting weaker defensive capabilities.

In summary, the Nasdaq 100 index fund offers an opportunity to share in the growth of America‚Äôs leading technology companies. Its excellent long-term returns come with greater short-term volatility, making it suitable for investors with a certain level of risk tolerance who can withstand significant fluctuations in net asset value.

Information Technology Sector Fund (VGT): Capturing the Overall Dividends of the Tech Industry

Section titled ‚ÄúInformation Technology Sector Fund (VGT): Capturing the Overall Dividends of the Tech Industry‚Äù

Information technology sector funds focus on investing in the IT industry. Take Vanguard‚Äôs Information Technology ETF (ticker: VGT) as an example: VGT tracks the MSCI US IMI Information Technology 25/50 Index, holding over 300 IT company stocks, including large-cap tech firms like Nvidia, Apple, Microsoft, and Broadcom, as well as numerous small and mid-cap tech companies. Similar to the Nasdaq 100, VGT is highly concentrated in the technology sector but offers broader coverage (not limited to Nasdaq-listed companies).

The purpose of including an IT sector fund in a portfolio is to capture the excess returns of the technology industry. Over the past decade, VGT has at times outperformed the Nasdaq 100, as small and mid-cap tech stocks contributed additional gains during tech booms. However, higher returns come with higher risks. The tech sector is often the first to be hit during interest rate hikes or market panics, and pure-tech ETFs experience larger drawdowns in volatile markets. During the 2022 tech bear market, VGT‚Äôs maximum drawdown was nearly -35%, slightly higher than the Nasdaq 100‚Äôs maximum drawdown during the same period.

This type of fund is more suitable for investors who are highly optimistic about the future of technology and have a strong personal risk tolerance. For those who have already achieved financial freedom or are experienced investors, a moderate allocation to pursue higher returns is feasible. However, ordinary investors with lower risk appetites can choose not to allocate to it or to reduce their allocation.

The 5:2:1 Allocation Strategy and Periodic Rebalancing

Section titled ‚ÄúThe 5:2:1 Allocation Strategy and Periodic Rebalancing‚Äù

For the three types of index funds discussed above, a straightforward portfolio strategy is to allocate them in a 5:2:1 ratio: approximately 62.5% to the S&P 500, 25% to the Nasdaq 100, and 12.5% to an information technology sector fund. The philosophy is as follows:

  • Core Holding (approx. 50%): The S&P 500 provides a stable foundation and broad diversification, capturing the average growth of the U.S. economy.
  • Satellite Holding (approx. 20%): The Nasdaq 100 enhances the portfolio‚Äôs long-term returns, sharing in the growth of large-cap tech.
  • Aggressive Holding (approx. 10%): The IT sector fund increases aggressiveness, providing greater elasticity during favorable economic cycles.

This portfolio balances stability and aggressiveness and can be fine-tuned according to individual circumstances. For example, conservative investors can reduce the weighting of the Nasdaq and tech funds (e.g., to 7:2:1 or 8:1:1), while aggressive investors can moderately increase the aggressive portion. The portfolio should be periodically rebalanced based on market changes and financial goals to restore the asset weights to their preset levels, thereby maintaining the desired risk-return profile.

Conclusion

Section titled ‚ÄúConclusion‚Äù

The S&P 500, Nasdaq 100, and information technology sector funds can form a three-pronged portfolio for long-term holding, combining a comprehensive and stable core with a high-growth engine that capitalizes on the technology wave. By adopting an appropriate allocation ratio based on their risk tolerance, and by adhering to a long-term investment strategy with periodic rebalancing, most investors can expect to achieve favorable risk-adjusted returns, fostering long-term wealth appreciation. Instead of frequent market timing and stock picking, it is more effective to build a simple and efficient index fund portfolio and hold it for the long term, navigating through bull and bear markets.

Rapidly Develop a HarmonyOS 6 Bluetooth Device Management App with Claude Code: Bluetooth Interaction, ArkTS Compilation Fixes, and TDD/BDD Practices

Sep 22, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Rapidly Develop a HarmonyOS 6 Bluetooth Device Management App with Claude Code: Bluetooth Interaction, ArkTS Compilation Fixes, and TDD/BDD Practices

Section titled ‚ÄúRapidly Develop a HarmonyOS 6 Bluetooth Device Management App with Claude Code: Bluetooth Interaction, ArkTS Compilation Fixes, and TDD/BDD Practices‚Äù

This article demonstrates how to quickly develop a Bluetooth device management app for Huawei‚Äôs HarmonyOS 6 using Claude Code. It covers typical features such as receiving Bluetooth advertisements, connecting to devices, setting the time, synchronizing status, performing infusions, and retrieving logs. The article also focuses on strategies for fixing ArkTS compilation errors and implementing TDD/BDD-oriented testing.

‚Äî Suitable for teams aiming to build BLE device applications through a ‚Äúwrite, test, iterate quickly‚Äù approach.

1. Development Goals and Device Protocol Overview

Section titled ‚Äú1. Development Goals and Device Protocol Overview‚Äù
  • Target Device: A Bluetooth device.
  • Typical Commands:
    • Read status, synchronize time, perform infusion, read records.

Implementation Files and Data Models:

  • entry/src/main/ets/utils/BleService.ets: An all-in-one wrapper for scanning and discovery, connection, notifications, and command sending.
  • entry/src/main/ets/utils/BleCommand.ets: Command construction (including CRC, length, and time/dose encoding).
  • entry/src/main/ets/utils/BleResponseParser.ets: Response parsing.
  • entry/src/main/ets/utils/BleAdvertisingParser.ets: Advertising data parsing (local name, UUID, manufacturer data, etc.).

2. How Claude Code Accelerates Native ArkTS Development

Section titled ‚Äú2. How Claude Code Accelerates Native ArkTS Development‚Äù
  • Code Navigation and Refactoring:
    • Quickly locate BLE-related entry points, cross-references, and dependencies using commands; maintain consistency with batch renaming and interface extraction.
  • Assisted Fixing of ArkTS Compilation Warnings/Errors:
    • Automatically points out rule violations like arkts-no-spread and unknown/any, suggesting replacement code and type completion.
  • Generating Test Skeletons and Adding Assertions:
    • Quickly create and extend unit tests and UI integration tests based on Hypium.

By combining these capabilities, a high-frequency feedback loop of ‚Äúmodify ‚Üí run tests ‚Üí analyze logs ‚Üí fix/refactor‚Äù can be established, significantly shortening the cycle from protocol design to an end-to-end working application.

3. Detailed Breakdown of the Bluetooth Interaction Flow

Section titled ‚Äú3. Detailed Breakdown of the Bluetooth Interaction Flow‚Äù

1. Receiving Bluetooth Advertisements (Scanning and Parsing)

Section titled ‚Äú1. Receiving Bluetooth Advertisements (Scanning and Parsing)‚Äù
  • Multi-path Scanning (HarmonyOS API v15+):
    • Entry Point: entry/src/main/ets/utils/BleService.ets startScan(...)
    • Event: BLEDeviceFind is continuously reported, internally using BleAdvertisingParser to parse the local name, service UUID, manufacturer data, etc.
  • Advertising Parsing: entry/src/main/ets/utils/BleAdvertisingParser.ets
    • Covers major AD types like Flags, Complete/Incomplete UUIDs, and Manufacturer Specific Data, making it easy to quickly identify the target device.

Associated Discovery Service: entry/src/main/ets/utils/BleDiscoveryService.ets encapsulates the discovery list, sorting by RSSI, automatic stopping on timeout, and a ‚Äútrusted device‚Äù caching strategy. The UI side can directly subscribe to status/result callbacks.

2. Connecting to a Device and Enabling Notifications

Section titled ‚Äú2. Connecting to a Device and Enabling Notifications‚Äù
  • After connecting and discovering services, you must ‚Äúsubscribe, then enable notifications, then read once more‚Äù before writing:
    • Enable Notifications: entry/src/main/ets/utils/BleService.ets
      • First, subscribe to the callback: gattClient.on('BLECharacteristicChange', ...)
      • Then, enable it: setCharacteristicChangeNotification(..., true)
      • Optionally, perform a readCharacteristicValue once to ‚Äúwarm up‚Äù the notification channel (required by some devices).
  • Notification Callback: entry/src/main/ets/utils/BleService.ets onCharacteristicChanged(...)
    • Use lowercase UUID comparison to avoid misses due to case differences.
    • Convert characteristic.characteristicValue to an ArrayBuffer before dispatching to a pending callback or a unified protocol parser.

3. Sending and Debugging Commands

Section titled ‚Äú3. Sending and Debugging Commands‚Äù
  • Sending a Write: entry/src/main/ets/utils/BleService.ets sendCommand(...)
    • ArkTS disables object spreading (no-spread), so characteristicValue must be modified directly before writing.
    • Uniformly output hexadecimal strings for easier troubleshooting: BleCommand.toHexString(...)
  • Command Construction:
    • Read Status: entry/src/main/ets/utils/BleCommand.ets
    • Synchronize Time: entry/src/main/ets/utils/BleCommand.ets
    • Infusion Command: entry/src/main/ets/utils/BleCommand.ets (dose √ó 1000 converted to an integer, written in little-endian).

4. Synchronizing Time and Reading Status

Section titled ‚Äú4. Synchronizing Time and Reading Status‚Äù
  • Synchronize Time: entry/src/main/ets/utils/BleService.ets, writes 0xA7 containing year, month, day, week, hour, minute, and second, then verifies through the notification channel upon completion.
  • Read Status: entry/src/main/ets/utils/BleService.ets ‚Üí Wait for notification ‚Üí Parse: entry/src/main/ets/utils/BleResponseParser.ets
    • Parses battery status, voltage/charge, remaining dose, single/daily limits, alarm bits, today‚Äôs usage, maximum log entries, etc.

5. Infusion

Section titled ‚Äú5. Infusion‚Äù
  • entry/src/main/ets/utils/BleService.ets calls buildInjectionCommand(dose).
  • entry/src/main/ets/utils/BleCommand.ets: The dose is encoded as a 4-byte little-endian integer with a precision of 1/1000, accommodating ‚Äúlarge/high-precision dose‚Äù scenarios.
  • Recommendations:
    • Perform pre-validation against the single/daily limits from the status, and split into packets or send in multiple parts if necessary.
    • Pay attention to MTU (typically 20 bytes) limitations and command length design.

6. Retrieving Logs (Record Parsing)

Section titled ‚Äú6. Retrieving Logs (Record Parsing)‚Äù
  • Notification Handling Dispatch: entry/src/main/ets/utils/BleService.ets processReceivedData(...)
    • The ‚Äú path calls record parsing: entry/src/main/ets/utils/BleResponseParser.ets parseRecord(...)
    • Supports two types of structured data: injection records and operation records.
  • If you need to ‚Äúfetch historical records by index/type,‚Äù you can add a READ_RECORD_WITH_TYPE constructor in BleCommand (a template is commented out in the project), which seamlessly integrates with the parsing logic above.

4. ArkTS Compilation Errors and Key Fixes

Section titled ‚Äú4. ArkTS Compilation Errors and Key Fixes‚Äù

Summary Document: docs/ble-arkts-fix-summary.md

  • Missing Class Properties:
    • For example, if connectionPromiseResolvers is not declared, it needs to be added as Map<string, () => void> for external resolution of connection Promises.
  • arkts-no-spread:
    • Object spreading is forbidden when writing characteristic values. Directly modify existing.characteristicValue = ... (see the BleService.ets section).
  • unknown/any and Loose Literals:
    • In notification callbacks, remove temporary Record<string, string>/unknown assertions and use strong typing instead.
  • Notification Matching and Logging:
    • Use lowercase UUID comparison and detailed logging of service/char UUID and hexadecimal payloads for easier on-site debugging.

These fixes, without changing business semantics, make the code satisfy both ArkTS semantics and Lint rules, resulting in a stable and maintainable build.

5. TDD and BDD Testing Practices

Section titled ‚Äú5. TDD and BDD Testing Practices‚Äù

1. Unit Testing (TDD)

Section titled ‚Äú1. Unit Testing (TDD)‚Äù
  • Device Discovery and Caching:
    • entry/src/ohosTest/ets/test/BleDiscoveryService.test.ets
    • entry/src/ohosTest/ets/test/DeviceCache.test.ets
  • Coverage Points:
    • Scan status flow, filtering by name, RSSI sorting, automatic stopping.
    • Trusted device marking, cache clearing, capacity limits, expiration statistics, etc.
  • Running Tests:
    • hvigor test
    • Filter by file: hvigor test --filter BleDiscoveryService

2. Behavior-Driven Development (BDD) and UI Integration

Section titled ‚Äú2. Behavior-Driven Development (BDD) and UI Integration‚Äù
  • Scenario Use Case: entry/src/ohosTest/ets/test/BleUIIntegration.test.ets
    • Start ‚Üí Begin Scan ‚Üí Discover Device ‚Üí Connect ‚Üí Sync Time/Refresh Status/Send Infusion ‚Üí Disconnect.
    • Utilizes @kit.TestKit‚Äôs Driver to find buttons, click, and assert, ensuring an end-to-end path ‚Äúfrom UI to protocol.‚Äù
  • Running Tests:
    • Full integration test: hvigor test --integration

3. Assertions and Timeout Strategies

Section titled ‚Äú3. Assertions and Timeout Strategies‚Äù
  • Most BLE steps are asynchronous callbacks: set reasonable timeouts for scanning/connecting/writing/notifications (e.g., 5‚Äì15s) to avoid false positives.
  • For critical UI text and buttons, try finding them multiple times to improve stability.
  • Use hexadecimal logs as an assertion aid (see BleService.ets/BleService.ets).

6. Practical Advice and Common Pitfalls

Section titled ‚Äú6. Practical Advice and Common Pitfalls‚Äù
  • Notification Order and ‚ÄúWarm-up‚Äù:
    • The sequence ‚Äúsubscribe ‚Üí enable notifications ‚Üí read once‚Äù can significantly improve the success rate of the first downstream response for some devices.
  • MTU and Command Length:
    • A typical BLE 4.2 MTU is only 20 bytes. Complex commands need to be split or the negotiation strategy on the device/firmware side needs to be upgraded.
  • Little-Endian Encoding and CRC:
    • The total command length, field encoding, and CRC16 (CCITT/False) calculation must be strictly aligned with the firmware.
  • Use HiLog Instead of console:
    • Use a unified domain/tag and %{public} output (see docs/hilog-migration-summary.md) for easier offline and on-site troubleshooting.
  • Permissions and Bluetooth Status:
    • Unified entry point: entry/src/main/ets/utils/BlePermissionManager.ets ensureBleReady(...). Handle permissions and adapter status all at once before starting a scan.

7. Conclusion and Next Steps

Section titled ‚Äú7. Conclusion and Next Steps‚Äù

Thanks to Claude Code‚Äôs ‚Äúcode navigation + compilation repair + test generation‚Äù features, we completed the entire cycle from protocol design to an end-to-end working solution with minimal back-and-forth:

  • Bluetooth Interaction: The full chain of scanning, connecting, notifications, commands, and record parsing is connected.
  • ArkTS Fixes: Strictly follows semantics and Lint rules for a stable build.
  • TDD/BDD: Unit and UI integration tests cover major scenarios, facilitating continuous regression.

Recommended Next Steps:

  • Add the READ_RECORD_WITH_TYPE command constructor in BleCommand to integrate with the existing parser and complete the ‚Äúfetch logs by index‚Äù feature.
  • Introduce more granular ViewModel layer state management and data persistence to create a complete ‚Äúcloud-device-edge‚Äù loop with record synchronization.
  • Refine exception codes and retry strategies to enhance robustness during network disconnection/reconnection.

  • Claude Code

  • Bluetooth Low Energy

Claude Code Automates Migration to HarmonyOS BLE v15+ for Multi-Scan and Connection Management

Sep 20, 2025
Vibe Sparking

TL;DR

Section titled ‚ÄúTL;DR‚Äù

The HarmonyOS BLE API version used in my previous project (v14 and earlier) had limitations such as single-scan restrictions and incomplete resource management.

Now, using Claude Code to generate and modify code, I was able to understand and automatically migrate to the latest HarmonyOS BLE API v15+, enabling multi-scan and more robust connection management.

Finally, I documented the complete migration process from v14 to v15+, focusing on multi-scan support, advertising data parsing, and connection management optimization.

Background

Section titled ‚ÄúBackground‚Äù

In the HarmonyOS ecosystem, BLE (Bluetooth Low Energy) is a crucial technology for interconnecting smart devices. As application demands have grown, the limitation of single-scan has become increasingly apparent, especially in scenarios requiring simultaneous scanning for multiple devices or services.

HarmonyOS introduced multi-scan support in API version 15, allowing applications to create multiple independent scanning instances, thereby improving resource management and scanning flexibility.

However, the existing project code was still based on the old API, leading to the following issues:

  1. Single-Scan Limitation: Only one scanning task could be performed at a time, failing to meet the demand for multi-device scanning.
  2. Incomplete Resource Management: Scanner instances were not managed independently, causing state confusion.
  3. Lack of Advertising Data Parsing: Scan results did not parse advertising data, affecting device information retrieval.
  4. Simple Connection Management: The absence of retry and automatic reconnection mechanisms compromised connection stability.

Objective

Section titled ‚ÄúObjective‚Äù

Based on the latest HarmonyOS BLE API v15+, refactor the existing BLE service code to achieve the following goals:

  1. Multi-Scan Support: Allow multiple scanning tasks to run simultaneously, with each task managed independently.
  2. Independent Resource Management: Each scanner instance is controlled independently to avoid conflicts.
  3. Complete Advertising Data Parsing: Implement parsing of BLE advertising data.
  4. Enhanced Connection Management: Implement connection retry and automatic reconnection mechanisms to improve connection stability.
  5. Modern Asynchronous Handling: Use Promise/async-await to handle asynchronous BLE operations.

Migration Process

Section titled ‚ÄúMigration Process‚Äù

1. Read Official Documentation

Section titled ‚Äú1. Read Official Documentation‚Äù

Before starting the migration, the first step was to download the official documentation to let Claude Code understand the new features and changes in HarmonyOS BLE API v15+.

2. Use Claude Code to Generate Migration Suggestions

Section titled ‚Äú2. Use Claude Code to Generate Migration Suggestions‚Äù

I provided the official documentation content to Claude Code and asked it to analyze the problems in the existing code and execute the steps to migrate to the latest API.

4. Code Review and Testing

Section titled ‚Äú4. Code Review and Testing‚Äù

I conducted a detailed review of the generated code to ensure it met project requirements and performed comprehensive testing on actual devices to verify the stability of the multi-scan and connection management features.

5. Summary Documentation

Section titled ‚Äú5. Summary Documentation‚Äù

Finally, I had Claude Code generate a complete summary document, recording the entire process of migrating from HarmonyOS BLE API v14 to v15+, including multi-scan support, advertising data parsing, and enhanced connection management features.

Core Changes

  • Better Error Isolation: Failure of a single scan does not affect other scans
  • Flexible Filter Configuration: Each scan can have its own independent filter conditions

Best Practices

    • Set a reasonable timeout
    • Clean up unnecessary scanners promptly

  2. Device Cache

    • Implement an expiration mechanism to avoid memory leaks
    • Retain information about recently discovered devices
    • Support quick reconnection

  3. Error Handling

    • Implement a retry mechanism
    • Use an exponential backoff strategy
    • Provide detailed error logs

  4. Resource Optimization

    • Set scanning parameters reasonably
    • Release GATT clients promptly

    • Batch process notification data

    • Periodically clean up expired devices
    • Limit cache size
    • Avoid memory leaks

Common Issues

Section titled ‚ÄúCommon Issues‚Äù

  1. No Scan Results

    • Check Bluetooth permissions
    • Verify that Bluetooth is enabled
    • Confirm that filter conditions are correct

  2. Connection Failed

    • Increase the number of retries
    • Extend the timeout period
    • Check if the device is in range

  3. Resource Leaks

    • Ensure all scanners are cleaned up
    • Close GATT clients correctly
    • Clean up event listeners

By following this guide, you can smoothly migrate from v14 to v15+, taking full advantage of the new API to provide a more stable and efficient BLE connection experience.

Hands-on with Closed-Loop AI Development: Building a ToDo App with Codex, Claude Code, and Gemini CLI

Sep 18, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Can AI truly develop a website independently now? This article shares a real experiment where three AI tools, each with a specific role, collaborated to complete the end-to-end development of a ToDo list application. We assigned them the following roles:

  • Codex: Project Manager (for requirements and acceptance criteria)
  • Claude Code: Development and Test Engineer
  • Gemini CLI: Code Review and Documentation Engineer

This process formed a closed-loop AI collaboration, from ‚ÄúRequirements Analysis -> Feature Implementation -> Automated Testing -> Review and Improvement -> Documentation.‚Äù

1. Codex: The AI Project Manager Defines the Requirements

Section titled ‚Äú1. Codex: The AI Project Manager Defines the Requirements‚Äù

Codex excels at transforming vague ideas into structured requirements. We gave it the concept of a ‚Äúto-do list website‚Äù and asked it to:

  • Output a functional requirements document
  • List quantitative acceptance criteria for each feature
  • Add exception and boundary scenarios

Example Prompt:

Codex produced content covering:

  • Basic functions: Add task / Mark as complete / Delete task
  • Task status display and update logic
  • Acceptance criteria examples:
    • The task should appear in the list immediately after being added.
    • Completed tasks should be styled differently from uncompleted ones.
    • The list should refresh instantly after deletion with no residual data.
  • Exception handling: Empty input, duplicate tasks, invalid characters, etc.

Key takeaways:

  • The more specific the prompt, the more complete the generated requirements.
  • Clearly defining ‚Äúbehavior + criteria‚Äù can be directly converted into test cases.

2. Claude Code: The AI Development Engineer Generates and Executes Code

Section titled ‚Äú2. Claude Code: The AI Development Engineer Generates and Executes Code‚Äù

Claude Code received the requirements document and started implementing the frontend, backend, and basic tests using React + Node/Express:

  • Frontend: Task input, display, status switching, and deletion interactions
  • Backend: Simple in-memory data storage + REST API (Create/Read/Update/Delete)
  • Supporting documents: README (running steps, dependency instructions)
  • Automated tests: Simulate adding/marking/deleting and assert status and list length

Example Prompt:

Claude‚Äôs execution characteristics:

  • Generated files by module (components, services, tests)
  • Ran tests while writing code, adjusting if they failed
  • Found and fixed minor issues, such as the list not refreshing immediately after deletion

Shortcomings (to be improved):

  • The initial UI was quite plain.
  • Task filtering/searching was not yet implemented.
  • Lacked persistence (in-memory only).

3. Gemini CLI: The AI Code Reviewer Inspects and Improves

Section titled ‚Äú3. Gemini CLI: The AI Code Reviewer Inspects and Improves‚Äù

Gemini CLI, as the review and summarization role, focused on:

  • Verifying if the functionality met the requirements and acceptance criteria
  • Pointing out gaps and areas for improvement
  • Generating a project summary and technical documentation

Example Prompt:

Example improvement suggestions from Gemini:

  • Add task filtering: All / Incomplete / Completed
  • Add search or pagination to handle a large number of tasks
  • UI enhancements: Status colors, placeholder text for empty lists, button accessibility
  • Introduce data persistence (file / SQLite / IndexedDB / LocalStorage)
  • Add error messages and input validation feedback
  • Add E2E tests (e.g., using Playwright)

Generated technical documentation structure (summary):

  • Project Introduction
  • Feature List and Corresponding Implementation
  • Tech Stack: React (Frontend SPA) + Axios (API calls) + Express (REST service)
  • Running Steps: Install dependencies -> Start backend -> Start frontend -> Access local port
  • Testing Instructions: Functional tests + extensible integration tests
  • Future Plans: Status filtering, persistence, permissions, multi-user support, multi-device adaptation

4. Summary of the Collaborative Loop‚Äôs Value

Section titled ‚Äú4. Summary of the Collaborative Loop‚Äôs Value‚Äù

Advantages:

  • Clear roles: A smooth flow from requirements ‚Üí implementation ‚Üí review ‚Üí documentation
  • Traceability: Acceptance criteria directly map to tests
  • Efficiency: Humans primarily focus on ‚Äúsupervision + direction‚Äù rather than tedious, repetitive work
  • Quality: Multiple AI model perspectives reduce oversights

Current limitations:

  • Complex business modeling still requires human abstraction.
  • Deeper performance, security, and concurrency issues still need professional evaluation.
  • Limited UI/UX innovation (biased towards functional correctness).

5. Directions for Further Iteration

Section titled ‚Äú5. Directions for Further Iteration‚Äù

Suggested priorities for expansion:

  1. Feature Layer: Status filtering / search / bulk operations / due dates / priorities
  2. Data Layer: Persistence (SQLite/Prisma) + simple identity system
  3. Testing Layer: E2E tests + performance metrics (first contentful paint, interaction latency)
  4. Architecture Layer: Service splitting / dependency injection / logging and error tracking
  5. Experience Layer: Accessibility (ARIA tags), responsive layout, light/dark mode
  6. Operations Layer: Containerized deployment + CI (build / test / lint / preview environment)

6. Quick Reusable Prompt Templates for Small Projects

Section titled ‚Äú6. Quick Reusable Prompt Templates for Small Projects‚Äù

Code Implementation:

Code Review and Documentation:

Conclusion

Section titled ‚ÄúConclusion‚Äù

This experiment demonstrates a compact, efficient, and replicable AI collaborative development loop: Codex clarifies the goal; Claude Code quickly produces and self-tests; Gemini CLI reviews, improves, and completes the documentation. AI can already significantly reduce boilerplate and repetitive work, allowing humans to focus on higher-level product and architectural thinking. Would you also like to try making AI your virtual ‚Äúsmall team‚Äù? Starting with a minimum viable product (MVP) is the best first step.

A thought to ponder: Will AI be able to independently complete more complex, multi-layered systems in the future? What are your views? Get hands-on, and perhaps the next accelerated workflow will be born in your side terminal.

A Real-World Guide to Using Large AI Models: From Horoscope Matching to Stock Trading and Healthcare

Sep 18, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Large AI models have already permeated our daily lives. This article guides you through their uses by demographic and scenario: emotional entertainment, investment and finance, health consultation, learning assistance, creative play, and advanced self-study.

Section titled ‚ÄúIntroduction‚Äù

‚ÄúHow can ordinary people use large AI models?‚Äù Different people have different needs: some are fascinated by horoscopes and relationships, some care about stocks, some ask about wellness, students want help with homework, and others just want to be creative. For Female Users: Horoscope Matching and Emotional Companionship

Section titled ‚ÄúFor Female Users: Horoscope Matching and Emotional Companionship‚Äù

Many people enjoy horoscopes, divination, and emotional comfort. AI can simulate a ‚Äúhoroscope master‚Äù or ‚Äúemotional advisor,‚Äù providing companionship and basic advice. It‚Äôs not psychic, but it excels at generating friendly, empathetic responses.

Recommended Tools: ChatGPT, Bing Chat. Suitable Uses: Horoscope matching, tarot card games, emotional support and comfort, writing heartfelt messages.

Example Prompts:

Tips:

  • Be specific in follow-up questions: e.g., ‚ÄúBe more specific, when might he appear? List 3 scenarios.‚Äù
  • You can request a structure: e.g., ‚ÄúOutput in three sections: ‚ÄòPersonality Complements,‚Äô ‚ÄòPotential Disagreements,‚Äô and ‚ÄòCommunication Advice.‚Äô‚Äù
  • Remember: It‚Äôs just for fun, don‚Äôt take it seriously.

Reminder: AI cannot predict the real future.

For Male Users: Assistance with Financial/Investment Analysis

AI can help organize company information, explain macroeconomic concepts, and draft analysis frameworks. It‚Äôs not a stock market guru‚Äîmore like a ‚Äúlogical but needs supervision intern.‚Äù

Recommended Tools: ChatGPT (for logical analysis), Bing/Bard (for the latest news), professional industry terminals (like Bloomberg, which ordinary users rarely access). Suitable Uses: Industry overview, financial structure comparison, risk enumeration, research report drafting.

Pitfalls to Avoid:

  • Ask it to list ‚Äúdata sources‚Äù and ‚Äúpoints needing double-checking.‚Äù
  • Don‚Äôt ask ‚Äúwhat stock is guaranteed to rise.‚Äù
  • Avoid relying on a single conclusion: demand the ‚Äúlogical chain.‚Äù

For Elderly Users: Health Consultation and Popular Science

Section titled ‚ÄúFor Elderly Users: Health Consultation and Popular Science‚Äù

AI can quickly provide information on diet, exercise, and common diseases. It‚Äôs suitable as a ‚Äúhealth encyclopedia + Q&A interface.‚Äù It does not replace a doctor‚Äôs diagnosis.

Recommended Tools: Bing Chat, ChatGPT, intelligent Q&A from health apps like Dingxiang Yisheng. Suitable Uses: Popular science on common symptoms, lifestyle reminders, basic explanation of health metrics.

Example Prompts:

Suggestions for Children Assisting Parents:

  • Help elders add a ‚Äúfor informational purposes only, confirm with a doctor‚Äù reminder.
  • Require the AI to flag ‚Äúuncertain/needs medical attention‚Äù situations.

Disclaimer: AI output does not replace professional medical diagnosis and prescription; for emergencies or medication, be sure to consult a doctor.

For Students: Homework Help and Writing Assistance

Section titled ‚ÄúFor Students: Homework Help and Writing Assistance‚Äù

AI can solve problems, create outlines, explain concepts, and grade essays. But don‚Äôt just copy‚Äîteachers can easily recognize the writing style.

Recommended Tools: Bing (for photo-based problem solving/web search), ChatGPT (for step-by-step writing guidance), Photomath/Zuoyebang (for targeted problem solving). Suitable Uses: Step-by-step derivations, restating knowledge points, essay structure, oral/translation practice.

Example Prompts:

The Right Way to Use It:

  • Ask it to ‚Äúgive hints first, not the final answer directly.‚Äù
  • Have the AI grade your draft instead of writing the whole thing for you.
  • Ask it to point out ‚Äúgrammatical errors + reasons for improvement.‚Äù

Recommendation: Use it to learn ‚Äúhow to solve problems,‚Äù not to ‚Äúlearn for you.‚Äù

For General Entertainment Users: Image/Video/Audio Creativity

For Advanced Education: Structured Review / Self-Testing / Self-Study Partner

Section titled ‚ÄúFor Advanced Education: Structured Review / Self-Testing / Self-Study Partner‚Äù

Use AI as an ‚Äúactive learning driver‚Äù: have it summarize, extract key points, create questions, grade, and role-play as a tutor.

  • Ask it to ‚Äúlist points you are unsure about or that might be incorrect.‚Äù

Pitfalls to Avoid:

Section titled ‚ÄúConclusion‚Äù

  • It‚Äôs a tool, not an authority

Interpreting and Analyzing OpenAI's Latest Paper 'How People Use ChatGPT'

Sep 18, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Introduction: A Global AI Revolution and Our Cognitive Blind Spots

Section titled ‚ÄúIntroduction: A Global AI Revolution and Our Cognitive Blind Spots‚Äù

In November 2022, OpenAI released its groundbreaking product, ChatGPT, to the public. Since its debut, the tool‚Äôs adoption rate has been astonishing. A working paper from the National Bureau of Economic Research (NBER Working Paper 34255), ‚ÄúHow People Use ChatGPT,‚Äù indicates that as of July 2025, ChatGPT had reached 700 million weekly active users, with over 2.5 billion messages exchanged daily, equivalent to approximately 29,000 messages per second. This unprecedented global diffusion rate led to its adoption by about 10% of the world‚Äôs adult population within just a few years. However, public and media understanding of this phenomenon often remains superficial. Most people view ChatGPT as a tool for content creation, programming, or simple chat, while its deeper social, economic, and human impacts remain hidden beneath the surface of everyday use.

This report will center on this pioneering study, co-authored by OpenAI‚Äôs research team and NBER, aiming to provide a comprehensive, multi-dimensional, in-depth interpretation and critical analysis. The report will go beyond the paper‚Äôs data presentation, clarifying contradictions between different studies and media reports through multi-party fact-checking, and exploring the profound trends, causal relationships, and potential impacts on future society embedded in these data from economic, sociological, and human motivation perspectives. Ultimately, this report will offer a rigorous yet insightful panoramic view of AI usage for the general reader, presented in an accessible style.

Part One: ChatGPT‚Äôs Phenomenal Growth: Multi-Party Verification of Facts and Data

Section titled ‚ÄúPart One: ChatGPT‚Äôs Phenomenal Growth: Multi-Party Verification of Facts and Data‚Äù

1.1 Core Data and Scale: Unprecedented AI Diffusion

Section titled ‚Äú1.1 Core Data and Scale: Unprecedented AI Diffusion‚Äù

The NBER working paper provides core data on ChatGPT‚Äôs growth. The report shows that from its release in November 2022 to July 2025, its weekly active users grew from millions to 700 million. Concurrently, daily messages soared from zero to over 2.5 billion. This growth rate not only far surpasses traditional technologies, such as Facebook taking four and a half years to reach 100 million users, but is also unparalleled in the field of AI technology. Other third-party statistical platforms, such as DemandSage, Nerdynav, and Seoprofy, in their reports published in mid-2025 or September, further confirmed this phenomenon. Data from these platforms indicate that ChatGPT‚Äôs weekly active users have reached or exceeded 800 million, with over 1 billion daily queries.

It is worth noting that there is a slight difference between the NBER report‚Äôs user count (700 million) and third-party reports (800 million). This discrepancy is not a contradiction in data but rather a direct reflection of the unprecedented exponential growth rate of AI technology. The technology is developing so rapidly that any static snapshot in time struggles to fully capture its dynamic entirety. The report‚Äôs data from July 2025 will be surpassed by higher figures in just a few weeks or months. This indicates that when analyzing the impact of AI, a dynamic rather than static perspective must be adopted. This speed itself is the most powerful signal of its disruptive impact on economic and social structures.

1.2 The Rise of Non-Work Uses: A New Perspective on AI Value

Section titled ‚Äú1.2 The Rise of Non-Work Uses: A New Perspective on AI Value‚Äù

For a long time, economic analysis of AI primarily focused on its impact on the productivity of ‚Äúpaid work.‚Äù However, the NBER report challenges this traditional narrative through its core data. Table 1 of the report clearly shows that from June 2024 to June 2025, the proportion of non-work-related messages on ChatGPT surged from 53% to 73%. This indicates that although the absolute number of work-related messages also continued to grow (from 213 million daily in June 2024 to 716 million daily in June 2025), its growth rate was far outpaced by non-work uses.

This shift in value reveals AI‚Äôs broader impact on human society. AI‚Äôs value is not only reflected in improving corporate efficiency but also creates immense value for ordinary people through ‚Äúhome production‚Äù and ‚Äúconsumer surplus.‚Äù For example, Collis and Brynjolfsson (2025) estimate that in 2024 alone, US consumers gained up to $97 billion in surplus value through generative AI. This finding suggests that AI‚Äôs scale in improving personal quality of life, time management, and non-economic activity efficiency may be comparable to, or even greater than, its impact on workplace productivity. This shift prompts us to rethink the true value of AI: it is evolving from a mere productivity tool into a ‚Äúlife tool‚Äù that profoundly affects our daily lives.

Part Two: Understanding User Behavior: Deconstructing Core Uses and Analyzing Deep Motivations

Section titled ‚ÄúPart Two: Understanding User Behavior: Deconstructing Core Uses and Analyzing Deep Motivations‚Äù

2.1 The ‚ÄúThree Pillars‚Äù: The Popular Logic of Practical Guidance, Information Seeking, and Writing

Section titled ‚Äú2.1 The ‚ÄúThree Pillars‚Äù: The Popular Logic of Practical Guidance, Information Seeking, and Writing‚Äù

The NBER report, through its innovative automated classification method, provides us with detailed insights into user behavior. The report points out that nearly 80% of ChatGPT user conversations are concentrated in three core categories: Practical Guidance, Seeking Information, and Writing.

Among these, practical guidance is currently the most common use case, encompassing a wide range of activities such as tutoring and teaching, operational instructions, and creative ideation. Of particular note, educational uses (e.g., tutoring/teaching) account for as high as 10% of all messages, demonstrating AI‚Äôs enormous potential in the education sector. Information seeking use cases are growing rapidly and are considered a powerful alternative to traditional search engines. This reflects users‚Äô increasing demand for instant, integrated answers, rather than just traditional link lists.

To understand user behavior more deeply, the report proposes a unique classification framework: ‚ÄúAsking‚Äù (asking questions/seeking advice) versus ‚ÄúDoing‚Äù (executing tasks/creating). Data shows that ‚ÄúAsking‚Äù messages are growing faster than ‚ÄúDoing‚Äù and have higher user satisfaction. This trend is not accidental. Whether seeking practical guidance (‚ÄúHow to cook?‚Äù) or obtaining information (‚ÄúWhat is quantum mechanics?‚Äù), the core driving force is to make better decisions and more effectively acquire and process information. This aligns with the NBER report‚Äôs finding that ‚ÄúAsking‚Äù messages are more favored by highly educated and high-income users, as high-quality decision-making is key to improving productivity in knowledge-intensive work. This finding suggests that ChatGPT‚Äôs true value may lie more in its role as a human ‚Äúcognitive co-pilot‚Äù to enhance decision-making and cognitive abilities, rather than as a ‚Äúlabor substitute‚Äù to automate tasks.

2.2 Writing: A Misunderstood Core Value of Work

Section titled ‚Äú2.2 Writing: A Misunderstood Core Value of Work‚Äù

Among all work-related messages, writing is the highest-proportion use case, accounting for an average of 40%. This data seems to confirm many people‚Äôs concerns that AI will completely replace human writers. However, the report delves deeper to reveal a crucial detail: among all ‚Äúwriting‚Äù messages, about two-thirds of the tasks are not ‚Äúfrom scratch‚Äù creation, but rather modification, editing, summarization, and translation of user-provided text.

This finding presents a subtle contrast to common perceptions. It indicates that in actual work, AI‚Äôs role is more about ‚Äúoptimization‚Äù than ‚Äúreplacement.‚Äù It helps humans refine existing ideas and content, rather than completely taking over. This finding echoes enterprise AI use cases in reports from companies like IBM and Moveworks. These use cases emphasize AI‚Äôs assistive role in content creation, such as generating ad copy drafts, email first drafts, or extracting key information from lengthy documents. This suggests that future workflows will be ‚Äúhuman-AI collaboration,‚Äù where AI frees humans from repetitive, low-value ‚Äúwriting‚Äù tasks, allowing them to focus more on higher-level thinking, strategy, and creativity.

Part Three: Correction and Reflection: The Truth About Controversial Uses and Cognitive Biases

Section titled ‚ÄúPart Three: Correction and Reflection: The Truth About Controversial Uses and Cognitive Biases‚Äù

3.1 Programming and Companionship: Media-Amplified Use Cases and Data Reality

Section titled ‚Äú3.1 Programming and Companionship: Media-Amplified Use Cases and Data Reality‚Äù

Regarding the prevalence of certain specific use cases, the NBER report‚Äôs findings differ significantly from some mainstream media narratives, revealing the complex reality of platform positioning and cognitive biases.

First, programming use cases. The NBER report indicates that programming-related messages account for only 4.2% of all messages on ChatGPT. This contrasts sharply with Handa et al.‚Äôs research on another AI assistant, Claude, which showed programming-related use cases as high as 33% in work scenarios.

Second, emotional companionship. The NBER report found that emotional companionship (relationships and personal reflection) accounted for only 1.9%, and games and role-playing for 0.4%, totaling a very small proportion. This is a stark contrast to Zao-Sanders and many media reports that list emotional companionship as a primary AI use case.

Why such a significant data gap? A major reason is the difference in platform positioning and user groups. Anthropic‚Äôs Claude platform is designed to be more geared towards technical and enterprise users, while Microsoft‚Äôs Copilot is deeply integrated into office software like Microsoft 365. In contrast, ChatGPT, as a general consumer-grade platform, has a broader user profile, leading to a relatively lower proportion of vertical use cases like programming. Furthermore, media reports about AI emotional companionship, virtual girlfriends, or ‚Äúdangerous‚Äù interactions often receive disproportionate attention due to their sensational nature. This ‚Äúsurvivor bias‚Äù leads to a serious overestimation of the universality of these use cases by the public. The NBER report, through large-scale, anonymous first-hand data, provides us with a more factual panoramic view, showing that these use cases remain niche on the consumer side.

3.2 Gender and Age Gap: A Dynamically Changing Social Landscape

Section titled ‚Äú3.2 Gender and Age Gap: A Dynamically Changing Social Landscape‚Äù

Regarding the demographic composition of AI user groups, especially the gender gap, there are also subtle differences between various studies. The NBER report points out that in the early days of ChatGPT‚Äôs release (late 2022), the user group was indeed predominantly male, with 80% of active users having typical male names. However, the report shows that this is a rapidly changing dynamic trend. By June 2025, this proportion had dropped to 48%, with female users even slightly outnumbering males. This trend aligns with the finding of accelerated AI user growth in low-income countries.

However, other third-party reports, such as those from Deloitte, Pew Research, and eWeek in 2025, still indicate a significant gender gap in AI, with male users accounting for approximately 65%. Behind these two seemingly contradictory conclusions are different research methods and data sources. The NBER report is based on first-party platform data, which can accurately track the dynamic changes in user groups (the gender composition of new users). Other studies, however, are mostly based on third-party traffic analysis or surveys, which may have biases, and their results more often reflect the historical stock of male users. The NBER data depicts a dynamic trend, where the popularization of AI is gradually correcting the early gender imbalance through the addition of new users. This process is overcoming socio-cultural barriers such as lower awareness of AI tools among women, lack of confidence, and moral concerns about ‚Äúcheating.‚Äù

Part Four: Scrutiny of Methodology: Beyond the Data Itself

Section titled ‚ÄúPart Four: Scrutiny of Methodology: Beyond the Data Itself‚Äù

4.1 Innovations and Advantages of the NBER Report‚Äôs Methodology

Section titled ‚Äú4.1 Innovations and Advantages of the NBER Report‚Äôs Methodology‚Äù

The NBER report‚Äôs prominence lies not only in its data conclusions but also in its unique and innovative research methodology. The report pioneered the use of ‚ÄúPrivacy-Preserving Automated Classification‚Äù and ‚ÄúData Clean Room (DCR)‚Äù protocols.

This method addresses the core contradiction in previous research between ‚Äúprivacy protection‚Äù and ‚Äúlarge-scale, fine-grained data analysis.‚Äù The report uses large language models (LLMs) rather than human labor to classify anonymous and de-identified conversational content, ensuring that human researchers never see user message content from start to finish. When analyzing sensitive data such as occupation and education, the research team adopted strict DCR protocols, further safeguarding user privacy by restricting query results (e.g., groups must exceed 100 users). This methodological innovation sets a new industry standard for future AI behavior research, achieving the goal of obtaining large-scale behavioral data without sacrificing user privacy.

4.2 Limitations and Potential Challenges

Section titled ‚Äú4.2 Limitations and Potential Challenges‚Äù

Despite its groundbreaking nature, the NBER report‚Äôs analysis also has inherent limitations. The report explicitly states that its analysis sample is limited to ChatGPT‚Äôs consumer plans (Free, Plus, Pro) and does not include enterprise-level applications (Business, Enterprise) or API usage.

This limitation is crucial because it means the picture painted by the report represents only the ‚Äútip of the iceberg‚Äù of AI‚Äôs impact. Enterprise users and consumers have fundamental differences in motivations, needs, and use cases. Enterprises are more concerned with high-value use cases such as ‚Äúautomation,‚Äù ‚Äúdata security,‚Äù and ‚Äúcustomization.‚Äù Compared to the ‚Äúcognitive co-pilot‚Äù mode dominated by ‚Äúpractical guidance‚Äù and ‚Äúinformation seeking‚Äù in the consumer version, enterprise AI (such as ChatGPT Enterprise or Claude API) is more often used for direct ‚Äúautomation‚Äù tasks like code generation, document summarization, and customer service automation. Therefore, the consumer behavior map depicted in the NBER report cannot fully reflect AI‚Äôs multiple roles in the entire economic system.

Summary and Outlook: Trends, Challenges, and Future Insights

Section titled ‚ÄúSummary and Outlook: Trends, Challenges, and Future Insights‚Äù

5.1 Summary of Core Arguments of the Report

Section titled ‚Äú5.1 Summary of Core Arguments of the Report‚Äù
  • The adoption rate of AI is unprecedented, and its value is shifting from workplace productivity to broader personal life efficiency and consumer surplus.
  • The core value of AI on the user side is not to ‚Äúreplace humans,‚Äù but to act as a ‚Äúcognitive co-pilot‚Äù to help humans make decisions and solve problems through ‚Äúpractical guidance‚Äù and ‚Äúinformation seeking.‚Äù
  • Media narratives about AI use cases (e.g., programming, emotional companionship) and user groups (e.g., gender gap) show significant discrepancies with facts revealed by large-scale data, reflecting the complex reality of platform differentiation and public cognitive lag.
  • AI research methodologies are progressing, but existing research still has inherent limitations, particularly in its inability to fully reflect the fundamental differences between consumer and enterprise AI use cases.

5.2 Reflections on the Future

Section titled ‚Äú5.2 Reflections on the Future‚Äù
  • Impact on the Economy: AI‚Äôs ‚Äúcognitive co-pilot‚Äù model will reshape knowledge-intensive work. Its core value will be to enhance human judgment, not to replace labor. This will create new demands for human soft skills such as ‚Äúcritical thinking‚Äù and ‚Äúquestioning ability.‚Äù
  • Impact on Society: As AI becomes more widespread among low-income countries and women, it is expected to become a new tool for narrowing the digital divide and gender gap. However, potential biases and data privacy risks still need to be guarded against.
  • Outlook for the Future: Trends indicate that we are moving from an era where AI is ‚Äútechnology‚Äù to an era where AI is a ‚Äúlifestyle.‚Äù In the future, AI will not only be a tool for improving work efficiency but also an indispensable part of personal growth, life management, and decision support. We must understand and adapt to this transformation with a critical and dynamic perspective, rather than being misled by static figures and one-sided narratives. The future of AI will be co-written by how humans collaborate and live with it.

Why rename the APK file?

Section titled ‚ÄúWhy rename the APK file?‚Äù

By default it‚Äôs app-release.apk. When sending to QA or uploading to CI artifacts, everything has the same name. It‚Äôs guesswork to identify versions ‚Äî frustrating and error-prone.

With a descriptive name you immediately know:

  • Which branch produced it
  • Which version it is
  • When it was built

Productivity goes up immediately.

What you need

Section titled ‚ÄúWhat you need‚Äù

  • A standard Flutter/Android project.

  • Any Android Gradle Plugin (AGP) version works, but naming approaches differ. The robust approach is to copy/rename after assemble. That‚Äôs the path used below and is widely adopted under newer AGP APIs.

  • Flutter‚Äôs --dart-define values are passed via Gradle -Pdart-defines as Base64. We can decode and read them in build.gradle.

Copy and use: add this to android/app/build.gradle

Section titled ‚ÄúCopy and use: add this to android/app/build.gradle‚Äù

Place under the android { ... } section with applicationVariants (Groovy syntax). Idea: get branch name + decode --dart-define + build the new file name + copy/rename after assemble. This ‚Äúcopy and rename‚Äù technique is more reliable across AGP versions.

Notes:

  • Local uses git rev-parse; CI can fallback to the GIT_BRANCH environment variable.
  • Newer AGP often breaks ‚Äúrename in place‚Äù; copy+rename is the portable approach.
  • See Flutter docs for build configuration locations and packaging steps.

How to pass --dart-define

Section titled ‚ÄúHow to pass --dart-define‚Äù

Command example:

Flutter encodes these --dart-define entries in Base64 and injects them as -Pdart-defines. The Gradle snippet above decodes them into a Map.

Common pitfalls (pre‚Äësolved here)

Section titled ‚ÄúCommon pitfalls (pre‚Äësolved here)‚Äù

  • In‚Äëplace rename sometimes fails New AGP Variant APIs changed. Community practice favors ‚Äúcopy + rename after assemble‚Äù.

  • Flutter output directory quirks Some builds land under flutter-apk/ or ignore outputFileName. Use the copy+rename fallback.

  • CI with detached HEAD git rev-parse can‚Äôt read the branch. Use env fallback (GIT_BRANCH or CI‚Äëspecific vars).

Engineer Growth Principles in the AI Era

Sep 16, 2025
Vibe Sparking

This article distills four often-overlooked yet crucial growth principles: argue less about who‚Äôs right and more for win‚Äìwins, ship first then optimize, don‚Äôt fear overlap‚Äîinsist on differentiation, and stop wasting time proving yourself.

Introduction

Section titled ‚ÄúIntroduction‚Äù

As AI advances at breakneck speed, engineers face not only a technical upgrade but also a test of worldview and workplace mindset. Have you ever alienated a colleague by clinging to ‚Äúbeing right‚Äù? Missed a window chasing perfection? These are common, and exactly what this piece explores. After years of trial and error, I‚Äôve refined four practical growth principles that continue to work in the real world. I hope they resonate.

1. Incentive Thinking: Don‚Äôt Argue Right vs. Wrong‚ÄîArgue for Win‚ÄìWin

Section titled ‚Äú1. Incentive Thinking: Don‚Äôt Argue Right vs. Wrong‚ÄîArgue for Win‚ÄìWin‚Äù

Early in my career, I was eager to prove I was ‚Äúright.‚Äù Over time I realized: in organizations, ‚Äúright‚Äù is rarely the most important thing‚Äî‚Äúwhat benefits the project/team‚Äù is. Obsessing over abstract ‚Äúelegance‚Äù and ‚Äúpure logic‚Äù while ignoring delivery, risk, resources, and ROI balance easily gets labeled as nitpicking.

Key mindset shifts:

  • From ‚ÄúI must win‚Äù to ‚ÄúDoes the team get better overall?‚Äù
  • From ‚Äútheoretical perfection‚Äù to ‚Äúmaximizing this iteration‚Äôs value‚Äù
  • From ‚Äúdebate positions‚Äù to ‚Äúcollaborative game ‚Üí win‚Äìwin options‚Äù

A practical trick: before speaking or rebutting, silently count to 5 and ask yourself:

  1. Will this statement move the decision or outcome forward?
  2. Is it fair and beneficial to both the other party and the team?
  3. Is there a way to express this with lower conflict cost?

Argue less about right/wrong, aim for win‚Äìwins, and your reputation as a collaborator‚Äîalong with your influence and trust‚Äîwill rise naturally.

2. No Premature Optimization: Ship First, Optimize After Validation

Section titled ‚Äú2. No Premature Optimization: Ship First, Optimize After Validation‚Äù

Perfectionism often delays the first version. When users haven‚Äôt validated and value isn‚Äôt closed-loop, pouring effort into performance, abstraction, and grand architecture is classic ‚Äúpremature optimization.‚Äù

The first version (V0 / MVP) has only two missions:

  • Validate there are real users who want it.
  • Validate the path is worth doubling down on.

Practice tips:

  • Set your ‚ÄúMinimal Success Level‚Äù (MSL) for this round.
  • Cap initial delivery investment (person-days / complexity / dependencies).
  • Leave room for refactoring instead of hard-locking the architecture up-front.
  • Track hypothesis ‚Üí ship ‚Üí feedback ‚Üí iteration cadence (accelerate loops, don‚Äôt just pile features).

When you see stable core usage + 100+ real, recurring users + paying signals or strong retention, that‚Äôs when systematic refactors/perf work actually pay off.

The mantra isn‚Äôt ‚Äúsettle for less,‚Äù it‚Äôs ‚Äúvalidate fast + optimize with purpose.‚Äù

3. Don‚Äôt Be Intimidated by Logic: It‚Äôs Fine If Others Did It‚ÄîBuild Your Difference

Section titled ‚Äú3. Don‚Äôt Be Intimidated by Logic: It‚Äôs Fine If Others Did It‚ÄîBuild Your Difference‚Äù

‚ÄúSomeone‚Äôs done it‚Äù isn‚Äôt a veto; it‚Äôs market proof and a learning sample. Differentiation isn‚Äôt only technical‚Äîoften it comes from:

  • Perspective: a new framing, entry point, or audience focus for the same problem
  • Experience: compressed flows, friction removal, instant feedback
  • Value exchange: open/closed source, subscription/one-off, tool + community hybrids
  • Narrative and persona: trust and cultural tone as invisible moats

Suggested execution steps:

  1. List a pros/cons matrix of existing solutions.
  2. Highlight under-served user scenarios and emotional pain points.
  3. Define your ‚ÄúDifferentiated Core‚Äù via subtraction: the smallest set that makes you distinct.
  4. Build a demo with perceivable differences first; collect real feedback, then expand.

Don‚Äôt overestimate the risk of ‚Äúrepetition‚Äù and underestimate the compounding of ‚Äúconsistency + differentiation + focus.‚Äù

4. Stop Proving Yourself: Spend Energy on Building and Joy

Section titled ‚Äú4. Stop Proving Yourself: Spend Energy on Building and Joy‚Äù

For technologists, the scarcest resource isn‚Äôt tools‚Äîit‚Äôs sustained, deep attention. Instead of bleeding energy in pointless debates and emotional tug-of-war, convert your will to win into building power.

Common self-draining traps:

  • ‚ÄúI must make them admit I know more.‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúTheir lack of recognition = I‚Äôm not good.‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúI must clap back at every jab.‚Äù

Replacements:

  • Let outcomes/code/metrics/demos speak.
  • Identify ‚Äúnon-productive debates‚Äù: not falsifiable + no decision rights + emotion-led.
  • Maintain a personal ‚Äúattention blacklist‚Äù: don‚Äôt trigger, don‚Äôt chase, don‚Äôt loop.
  • Build positive loops: output (articles/open source/prototypes) ‚Üí feedback ‚Üí improvement.

Let your work establish your identity and reputation‚Äînot momentary keyboard wins.

Final Thoughts

Section titled ‚ÄúFinal Thoughts‚Äù

To recap the four principles:

  1. Argue less about right/wrong; aim for win‚Äìwins.
  2. Validate value first; then refine and optimize.
  3. Don‚Äôt fear overlap; insist on differentiation.
  4. Don‚Äôt waste energy proving; commit to sustained creation.

In the AI era, tool dividends are accelerating ‚Äúcapability depreciation.‚Äù Knowing a stack is no longer a lasting moat. What compounds sustainably is:

  • Mindset flexibility
  • Strategic execution
  • Differentiated expression
  • Focus and continuous retrospection

The path of growth is inevitably winding. If your direction is right, the distance won‚Äôt matter. May we embrace the technological tide while consolidating inner judgment and creativity.

  • AI

2025 U.S. Valuation Logic: AI, Nuclear, Quantum, Rare Earths ‚Äî What‚Äôs Real and What‚Äôs Hype?

Sep 16, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Retail investors may have noticed recently that shares of several U.S.-listed companies involved in frontier technologies have surged. This report analyzes their core businesses, the drivers behind the rallies, the degree of disconnect between valuation and fundamentals, the sustainability of their business models, industry trends and market sentiment, and each company‚Äôs moat and competitiveness‚Äîso you can better understand the logic, risks, and opportunities behind lofty valuations.
