Codex Gets Slash Commands: Save Prompts as /commands for One‚ÄëTap Reuse

Sep 16, 2025
Vibe Sparking

You can now write your frequently used prompts in Markdown, drop them into ~/.codex/prompts/, and call them in Codex with /command. This speeds up workflows immediately. Community reports confirm it works well in the CLI, and setup is simple (npm i -g @openai/codex or brew install codex).

Note: As you observed, it currently doesn‚Äôt support directory‚Äëscoped prefixes. In my testing too, it‚Äôs strictly ‚Äúfilename = command name,‚Äù with no namespace from subfolders.

Why use it now?

Section titled ‚ÄúWhy use it now?‚Äù

The real time‚Äësaver is prompt reuse. Turn high‚Äëfrequency prompts‚Äîlike ‚Äúcode review,‚Äù ‚Äúgenerate tests,‚Äù or ‚Äúrelease checklist‚Äù‚Äîinto /review, /tests, and /ship. Type once, reuse anywhere. Codex has been rapidly improving its CLI/IDE experience, so it‚Äôs a great time to standardize your prompts.

Even better, this pattern mirrors Claude Code‚Äôs ‚Äúcustom slash commands‚Äù: store prompts as Markdown, recall with a slash. The migration cost is near zero.

Three‚Äëstep quickstart

Section titled ‚ÄúThree‚Äëstep quickstart‚Äù

1) Create the folder
Make sure ~/.codex/prompts/ exists (create it if not).

2) Add a Markdown file
For example, create review.md with content like:

‚ÄúYou are a code review assistant. Provide structured feedback on: security, performance, complexity, readability, and test gaps. Output with clear bullets.‚Äù

3) Restart your Codex session
Open Codex, type /revi‚Ä¶ and it will autocomplete to /review. Press Enter to run. This matches community reports on folder usage and behavior.

Practical tips:

  • Command name = filename (without .md).
  • Avoid collisions with built‚Äëins (don‚Äôt take names like /init).
  • New files are most reliably recognized after starting a new session.

Current limitations and workarounds

Section titled ‚ÄúCurrent limitations and workarounds‚Äù

  • No directory‚Äëscoped prefixes
    You can‚Äôt map backend/review.md and frontend/review.md to different /reviews. Add suffixes like review-fe.md and review-be.md instead.

  • Parameters/placeholders are limited
    Some users report @‚Äëstyle parameters are unreliable. A reliable approach: trigger the command first, then add concrete context in the next turn.

  • Short, memorable names win
    Think of the slash menu like VS Code/Cursor quick actions‚Äîshort names you can remember and type fast. Follow community best practices and conventions.

5 ready‚Äëto‚Äëuse high‚Äëleverage commands

Section titled ‚Äú5 ready‚Äëto‚Äëuse high‚Äëleverage commands‚Äù

  • /review: Structured code review (security/performance/complexity/readability/tests).

  • /tests: Generate table‚Äëdriven/parameterized tests and cover edges.

  • /ship: Pre‚Äërelease/release checklist (migration, rollback, monitoring, canary scope).

  • /hotfix: Fast triage and minimal‚Äëblast‚Äëradius fix plan.

  • /release-notes: Human‚Äëreadable notes + tweet‚Äëlength announcement.

Save each snippet above as a .md file in ~/.codex/prompts/. After restarting your session, they‚Äôll show up via /.

Use it alongside Claude Code

Section titled ‚ÄúUse it alongside Claude Code‚Äù

If your team mixes Codex + Claude Code, standardize reusable flows as Markdown prompts and use each tool‚Äôs slash menu. Both sides can consume the same files, reducing cognitive load. The Claude community also encourages this prompt‚Äëas‚ÄëMarkdown approach.

Closing

Section titled ‚ÄúClosing‚Äù

Standardizing and modularizing prompts is a key step in turning AI coding from ‚Äúinspiration‚Äù into ‚Äúprocess.‚Äù
Starting today, put your top 3 prompts into ~/.codex/prompts/ and let your fingers remember the joy of /.

Section titled ‚ÄúIntroduction‚Äù

You can feel the wind shifting. AI is no longer just ‚Äúcompleting a few lines of code.‚Äù It has started to string together the entire engineering loop: requirements, design, implementation, testing, deployment, and operations/retro. That‚Äôs what I call Vibe Coding ‚Äî an engineering approach that is anchored by architecture, operated by agents, and measured by closed loops.

The data backs this up: the share of developers using or planning to use AI tools has risen from 76% in 2024 to 84% in 2025, yet trust has declined. ‚ÄúUsing‚Äù and ‚Äúusing well‚Äù are not the same.

Bottom line first: Vibe Coding is an ‚Äúera bonus‚Äù for 35+ architects. You carry systems thinking, hard‚Äëwon engineering experience, and business context. AI can outsource the repetitive, mechanical, error‚Äëprone parts. It can 10x your ‚Äúabstraction and constraint‚Äù leverage ‚Äî not exaggerating; mainstream studies suggest very real productivity gains from tens of percent to multiples.

What Is Vibe Coding?

Section titled ‚ÄúWhat Is Vibe Coding?‚Äù

In one sentence: Turn AI into your ‚Äúengineering squad.‚Äù You are the chief designer; it handles the grunt work and the wiring.

A practical six‚Äëstep closed loop:

  1. Requirements ‚Üí Scenario use cases: translate business goals into verifiable stories and constraints.
  2. Architecture ‚Üí Constraints and interfaces: lock boundaries with ADRs and interface contracts.
  3. Implementation ‚Üí Agent division of labor: codegen, library retrieval, dependency install, environment setup.
  4. Verification ‚Üí Test‚Äëfirst: regression suites and coverage thresholds.
  5. Integration ‚Üí CI/CD: PR bots, automated review, staged rollout.
  6. Observability ‚Üí Feedback loops: logs, metrics, rollback, data feedback.

This isn‚Äôt hand‚Äëwaving. End‚Äëto‚Äëend benchmarks like SWE‚Äëbench have brought ‚Äúcan AI actually fix real bugs and pass tests‚Äù into daylight. Systems such as OpenHands and Refact have placed high on leaderboards, showing closed‚Äëloop AI engineering is rapidly approaching the practical line.

Why Is This the Biggest Perk for 35+ Architects?

Section titled ‚ÄúWhy Is This the Biggest Perk for 35+ Architects?‚Äù

Because you hold three rare assets:

  • System‚Äëlevel abstraction: you know what to do and what not to do. AI needs guardrails.
  • Engineering cadence: you‚Äôve lived through versioning, dependencies, environments, and regressions. AI fears ‚Äúno constraints.‚Äù
  • Domain context: you understand data definitions, compliance, SLAs. AI doesn‚Äôt read the ‚Äúunwritten rules,‚Äù you do.

Research backs the reality: when enterprises land generative AI in software development, overall speed improves materially, and with proper governance ‚Äúthe same team can ship more.‚Äù But governance and method are key ‚Äî otherwise you end up ‚Äúfast and wrong.‚Äù

Your moat is exactly this: channel AI‚Äôs ‚Äúspeed‚Äù into a predictable engineering process. That‚Äôs where Vibe Coding sits.

The Truth: ‚ÄúGeniuses Don‚Äôt Need It; Ordinary Folks Can Trip Over It‚Äù

Section titled ‚ÄúThe Truth: ‚ÄúGeniuses Don‚Äôt Need It; Ordinary Folks Can Trip Over It‚Äù‚Äù

Linus summed up AI sharply: ‚Äú90% marketing, 10% reality.‚Äù He has also said he expects practical tooling like bug finding ‚Äî the ‚Äúpride and pragmatism‚Äù of masters.

DHH‚Äôs stance is similar: AI is fine for drafting and API lookup; the real joy is in typing the code yourself. Hacker geniuses don‚Äôt need ‚Äúautomated closed loops‚Äù to ship.

So why do ordinary people often face‚Äëplant?

The core issue isn‚Äôt ‚Äúcan a model write a few lines of code,‚Äù but can you run requirements ‚Üí design ‚Üí implementation ‚Üí verification ‚Üí deployment ‚Üí observability as a repeatable loop. Without that loop, you might ‚Äúuse AI to write code‚Äù every day yet only accumulate half‚Äëfinished parts and a bug spiral.

The data already signals it: in 2025, developer sentiment toward AI has dropped while distrust has risen ‚Äî treating AI outputs as ‚Äúanswers,‚Äù instead of ‚Äúartifacts to be verified,‚Äù sends you off course quickly.

Typical failure patterns (common among outsiders / low‚Äëexperience programmers):

  1. Requirements drift: no clear acceptance criteria ‚Üí prompts keep getting longer ‚Üí results drift farther.
  2. Structural entropy: no governance for directories, module boundaries, env vars, or dependency versions ‚Üí unmaintainable in weeks.
  3. Blind bug‚Äëfixing: no test baseline ‚Üí manual clicking ‚Üí fix one, break three.
  4. Broken data loop: no events/metrics captured ‚Üí no activation, retention, or value evidence.
  5. Invisible cost/risk: model calls without quotas, caching, or auditing ‚Üí cost and compliance spiral together.
  6. Always ‚Äúfast to generate,‚Äù never ‚Äústrict on regression‚Äù: no minimum regression set ‚Üí delivery quality is luck.
  7. Only ‚Äúprompt tuning,‚Äù never ‚Äúinterface + constraint design‚Äù: agent artifacts lack consistency ‚Üí reuse fails.

The real gap: closed‚Äëloop thinking relies on long‚Äëterm accumulation of abstraction and constraint skills, usually built over 5‚Äì10 years of:

  • CS fundamentals (compilers, OS, database normal forms, algorithms and data structures)
  • Engineering practice (version control, dependency governance, performance and incident triage, CI/CD)
  • Architectural tradeoffs (consistency vs. throughput, latency vs. cost, failure domains vs. ownership)

The Vibe Coding Playbook (Minimal, Practical)

Section titled ‚ÄúThe Vibe Coding Playbook (Minimal, Practical)‚Äù

Principles

Section titled ‚ÄúPrinciples‚Äù
  1. Constraints before generation: define contracts, interfaces, schemas, and acceptance criteria before asking AI to generate.
  2. Test first, always: even a tiny regression pack is better than nothing.
  3. Traceability: version your prompts, inputs, and outputs; attach artifacts to PRs.
  4. Guardrails: regex/structured checks, secondary critic models, cost and timeout budgets.
  5. Human in the loop ‚Üí remove over time: automate the critical path as confidence grows.

A Minimal Six‚ÄëArtifact Kit

Section titled ‚ÄúA Minimal Six‚ÄëArtifact Kit‚Äù
  • ADR template + interface contracts (OpenAPI/JSON Schema)
  • Minimal regression tests (happy path + 1‚Äì2 edge cases)
  • PR bot checklist (schema changes, migration, test impact)
  • Observability baseline (structured logs + 5 key metrics + trace on critical path)
  • Cost/prod budget dashboard (model $/user/week, error rate, timeout)
  • Rollback and canary switch

Agent Roles (Example)

Section titled ‚ÄúAgent Roles (Example)‚Äù
  • Generator: code, docs, summaries, drafts
  • Checker: compliance, duplicates, risk flags
  • Orchestrator: multi‚Äëstep flows (ingest ‚Üí clean ‚Üí structure ‚Üí persist)

A 90‚ÄëDay Closed‚ÄëLoop Plan (Solo/Small Team)

Section titled ‚ÄúA 90‚ÄëDay Closed‚ÄëLoop Plan (Solo/Small Team)‚Äù

Phase A (Weeks 1‚Äì4): Problem Framing and Data

Section titled ‚ÄúPhase A (Weeks 1‚Äì4): Problem Framing and Data‚Äù
  • Pick a scenario: high frequency + clearly measurable savings + easy data access.
  • Five lines: problem ‚Üí user ‚Üí value ‚Üí data ‚Üí willingness to pay.
  • Baseline data/ground truth: sample 50‚Äì200 items; define acceptance criteria.
  • Minimal product spec: 1 core path, 2 safeguards, 1 success KPI.
  • Aligned metrics: activation (first core action < 60s), retention (7‚Äëday revisit rate), unit value (time saved or cost reduced).
  • Pricing hypothesis: model (seat / usage / tiered subscription) + price anchor research.

Phase B (Weeks 5‚Äì8): Core Loop and AI Enablement

Section titled ‚ÄúPhase B (Weeks 5‚Äì8): Core Loop and AI Enablement‚Äù
  • Core loop: acquisition ‚Üí activation ‚Üí value realization ‚Üí feedback into models/rules/recommendation.
  • Agent division of labor:
    • Generation: docs/summaries/strategy drafts
    • Checking: compliance/duplication/risk flags
    • Orchestration: multi‚Äëstep data flow (scrape ‚Üí clean ‚Üí structure ‚Üí store)
  • Sustainable data: unified schema (events + business + model prompt context); build a minimal, high‚Äëquality label set.
  • Iteration cadence: ship weekly (changelog + metric comparison) to 5‚Äì10 gray users.
  • Trust guardrails: prompt versioning, output validation (regex/rules/critic model), cost monitoring ($/user/week).

Phase C (Weeks 9‚Äì12): Monetization and Steady State

Section titled ‚ÄúPhase C (Weeks 9‚Äì12): Monetization and Steady State‚Äù
  • Payments and access: Stripe/Lemon Squeezy/Paddle; control rate/features by plan.
  • Observability: logs (structured), metrics (core funnels + cost), traces (critical path), and alerting.
  • Ops automation: trial expiry nudges, low‚Äëusage wakeups, weekly usage insights (AI‚Äëgenerated).
  • Risk/compliance: data masking, model call allowlist, SBOM and version baselines.
  • Growth experiments: A/B onboarding variants (prompts/sample data) ‚Üí activation impact.
  • Expansion: when weekly new paid growth slows and retention is healthy ‚Üí evaluate a second curve or vertical packs.

Closed‚ÄëLoop Readiness (‚â•80% means ‚Äúloop is running‚Äù)

Section titled ‚ÄúClosed‚ÄëLoop Readiness (‚â•80% means ‚Äúloop is running‚Äù)‚Äù
  1. ‚â•10 real external users use it for 4 consecutive weeks
  2. A single value KPI (time saved / automation success / detection recall) trends up stably

  3. 10% trial‚Äëto‚Äëpaid validation samples

  4. Critical path fully automated (no manual intervention) + safe rollback
  5. ‚â•70% of generated content passes automatic quality checks; no high‚Äërisk misuse cases

Minimal Metrics & Dashboard

Section titled ‚ÄúMinimal Metrics & Dashboard‚Äù
  • Acquisition: signup conversion rate / CAC (can start at 0)
  • Activation: first core action ‚â§ 60s completion rate
  • Value: weekly time saved per user (self‚Äëreported + spot‚Äëchecked) or automated tasks completed
  • Retention: D7 / D30
  • Revenue (optional): trial‚Üípaid conversion / ARPU
  • Cost: model call cost per user per week; error and timeout rates
  • Quality: manual sampling pass rate of generated outputs; regression pass rate

Typical Stack (Trim as Needed)

Section titled ‚ÄúTypical Stack (Trim as Needed)‚Äù
  • Frontend: Next.js / SvelteKit + Tailwind
  • Backend: FastAPI / Bun + tRPC / GraphQL
  • Data: Postgres + Redis (cache / job queue) + DuckDB (ad‚Äëhoc analytics)
  • Model layer: OpenAI / Claude / local (Ollama) + vector DB (pgvector / Qdrant)
  • Orchestration: LangGraph / custom function router
  • Events & jobs: n8n / Temporal (can defer)
  • Monitoring: OpenTelemetry + Loki / Tempo / Prometheus
  • Payments/licensing: Stripe / Lemon Squeezy
  • Observability UI: Metabase / Grafana + custom metrics

Landing Tips

Section titled ‚ÄúLanding Tips‚Äù
  • Don‚Äôt over‚Äëengineer multitenancy early; start single‚Äëtenant with permission isolation
  • Start with rules + validation, then introduce free‚Äëform model generation
  • Cache model calls (prompt hash + semantic similarity)
  • Weekly changelogs are for users, not yourself
  • Remove one low‚Äëusage feature every week to keep the core crisp
  • Small, high‚Äëquality labeling loops beat blind scaling

Risks and ‚ÄúFool‚ÄëProofing‚Äù

Section titled ‚ÄúRisks and ‚ÄúFool‚ÄëProofing‚Äù‚Äù
  • Accuracy/trust: usage and hype rise while trust drops ‚Äî counter with tests and review.
  • IP/compliance: clarify model/data boundaries and terms.
  • Quality and security: adopt security baselines, dependency allowlists, SBOM, signing, and supply‚Äëchain scanning.
  • Over‚Äëreliance: keep manual takeover and rollback for critical paths.

The ‚ÄúH200 Era‚Äù Engineering Dividend

Section titled ‚ÄúThe ‚ÄúH200 Era‚Äù Engineering Dividend‚Äù

Hardware is accelerating too. H200 improves bandwidth and memory, lifting both retraining and inference throughput. Compute is no longer an absolute moat for mid‚Äësized teams. Whoever runs closed loops first, harvests first.

Closing

Section titled ‚ÄúClosing‚Äù

Pick a ‚Äúhigh‚Äëfrequency + measurable savings + easy data‚Äù scenario, and in 90 days get four things working: validated value ‚Üí guarded generation ‚Üí observable metrics ‚Üí a path to cashflow. That‚Äôs a Vibe Coding closed‚Äëloop win for architects.

What idea in your head best fits this today? Write it in five lines ‚Äî problem ‚Üí user ‚Üí value ‚Üí data ‚Üí paid ‚Äî then go.

Geniuses don‚Äôt need Vibe Coding to prove themselves. Working architects can turn ‚Äúexperience ‚Üí productivity‚Äù directly into revenue. The window is 2025‚Äì2026. Make your methodology concrete as constraints, tests, and process ‚Äî let AI do the rest. While others wrestle with ‚Äútrust,‚Äù you have the loop humming and the P&L flowing.

AI‚Äôs Golden Tipping Point: 10% Penetration and Industry Reshaping

1. Key Takeaways at a Glance

Section titled ‚Äú1. Key Takeaways at a Glance‚Äù
  • 9.7% enterprise AI adoption ‚âà about to cross the 10% threshold ‚Üí moving from the ‚Äútrial phase‚Äù to the ‚Äúscale-up phase‚Äù
  • Technology diffusion follows an S‚Äëcurve: the 10%‚Üí50% band is often the ‚Äúgolden period‚Äù for investment and value realization
  • AI will diffuse faster than past mainstream waves (cloud / smartphones / SaaS), driven by reusable foundation models, API ecosystems, compute-as-a-service, and agentic development
  • Leading industries share: high data density + frequent decisions + large automation surface
  • AI is shifting from an ‚Äúefficiency tool‚Äù to a ‚Äústrategic nerve center‚Äù and ‚Äúgrowth lever‚Äù

2. Why the Inflection Now?

Section titled ‚Äú2. Why the Inflection Now?‚Äù

Goldman Sachs reports that by August 2025, US enterprise AI adoption reached 9.7% (approaching the 10% threshold). Historically, this marks the moment when the ‚Äúearly majority‚Äù starts to enter at scale:

  1. Follower risk perception declines (validated cases + falling costs)
  2. Budgets shift from ‚Äúpilots‚Äù to ‚Äúintegration / process re‚Äëengineering‚Äù
  3. Org structures and governance evolve (AI PM / AI Ops / data risk & controls)

Rule of thumb: as penetration advances from ~10% to 50%, compound growth is steepest and both valuation elasticity and industry dividends expand in tandem.
